chapter.title: Video Settings
chapter.para: This chapter describes how to setup your video settings in Scenic. How course, Scenic can transmit video to a remote peer.
Each peer configures its video capture size and chooses the right device. Next, when using analog capture device, the video standard can be PAL or NTSC.

Scenic is designed so that configuring the video codec must be done by the receiver. This way, the receiver can fine tune the quality of the image it receives. On the receiver's side, the operator can also choose to display the window in full screen on a specific display. This is also where the user chooses the jitter buffer for the video stream. Increase it to prevent poor image quality in case of packets loss. Increasing the jitter buffer add mores latency, so it is better to have a sane network with close to no packets loss, instead of increasing this value.

sect1.title: Sending Video
sect1.para: In this section, it is possible to configure the video image that will be sent to your remote peer.

sect2.title: Preview
sect2.para: The preview option will show you the video you are actually capturing, (The one you will send to the receiver) This enable you to validate that you are actually capturing a video feed.

sect2.title: Video Source
sect2.para: Here you can choose witch video source you want to use to send. To make a color test, you can use the Color bars. Scenic detects which supported video devices are connected to your computer, and lists them there. It tries to detect them every tiem the user switches to the video tab, and when trying to initiate a streaming session with a peer. That means that if you don't see a video device you have just plugged, you could try switching to an other tab, and switching back to the video tab, to see if it is detected.

sect2.title: Video Input
sect2.para: Some devices have many input, such as S-Video, composite, etc. In this case, you must choose the input to which the camera is connected to.

If using an analog video capture card, S-Video is generally preferable over a composite input, since it offers a better image quality, especially for colors. A component input is even better. S-Video is an analog video signal that carries video data as two separate signals: luma (luminance) and chroma (color). This differs from composite video, which carries picture information as a single lower-quality signal, and component video, which carries picture information as three separate higher-quality signals.

sect2.title: Video Standard
sect2.para: When using an analog video capture card, this configuration entry must be set accordingly to the video standard of the camera. Most of the Americas, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Burma, and some Pacific island nations and territories use NTSC. The rest of the world use PAL

PAL: Phase Alternate Line, is an analogue television encoding system used in broadcast television systems in large parts of the world. Many European country uses this standard. NTSC: National Television System Committee, is the analog television system used in most of North America, South America, Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Burma, and some Pacific island nations and territories.

sect2.title: Aspect Ratio
sect2.para: The aspect ratio of an image is the ratio of the width of the image to its height. Scenic currently supports 4:3 and 16:9. Finally, the aspect ratio can be 4:3 or 16:9, depending on if the image source provides square pixels or rectangle pixels. Commonly used values are 16:9 for 704x480 and 4:3 for 640x480

sect2.title: Video Codec
sect2.para: Choose h.263 for low bandwidth or low CPU setup. Use Theora for a patent-free experience. Use MPEG4 for most situation. Use h.264 to use all the CPU power you have.

sect2.title: Video Bitrate
sect2.para: Video bitrate is the number of bits of video data that are conveyed or processed per unit of time. It is expressed in Mega bits per second. Video bitrate capabilities varies depending of the video codec used:

entry.para: 16 Mbps, seems to be limited only by CPU
Most CPU-intensive (though scales to multiple cores) and most latency.
100 kbps (will go to 500 kbps with motion)
4Mbps (generally will be stay at 3Mbps without a lot of motion)
Preferable tradeoff for CPU-cost + Latency vs. Quality.

Bitrate variable, depends largely on image source material. Doesn't like sudden, extreme changes in light (results in stuttering). Least CPU-intensive, lowest latency, reasonable quality at higher bitrate.
Quality engine is much more reliable than using the bitrate setting. Tends to stutter with static, homogenous source material (i.e. camera pointed at wall) for low quality setting.

sect2.title: Fullscreen
sect2.para: You have an option to automatically launch the receiver's window in fullscreen. Once the receiver's window is running, you can press the Escape (or F) key to toggle on and off the fullscreen mode.

sect2.title: X11 Display
sect2.para: Useful to display the video on another monitor.

sect2.title: Deinterlace
sect2.para: Deinterlacing makes a nicer image when the source is analog, but it adds latency. You should never use it if the remote video source is a Web cam.
